thread.title: Boys Soccer: Early goal propels Pequannock
thread.title_full: Boys Soccer: Early goal propels Pequannock

title: Boys Soccer: Early goal propels Pequannock
text:
'We're playing some really high quality teams, which will give us that preparation to get to states.' 
Pequannock head boys soccer coach 
Michael Zummo 
PEQUANNOCK - With the night centered around acknowledging the seniors, it was the seniors who provided the key scoring strikes and defensive stops, as the Golden Panthers used the momentum from finding the back of the net first to propel them to their third victory in a row over the Hanover Park Hornets. 
Following a first half goal off a volleyed blast from senior Matt Thomas to open the scoring, the Golden Panthers (10-6-1) added two more goals in the second to come away with a 3-0 victory over the Hornets (6-9-1). 
Golden Panthers head coach Michael Zummo said the opening goal, "meant everything." 
"I think the momentum was everything," he said. "We needed that to get our heads going, get the confidence, and continue playing good soccer." 
With both teams creating chances in the early going, it was the Golden Panthers who found the right combination first around the 28' minute. 
Having just taken possession just past midfield near the left sideline, junior Ethan Blakely lofted a ball towards the far post in the direction of Thomas, who blasted it home on the volley, leaving the Hornets goalkeeper no chance. 
Zummo said that goal "was one of the prettier goals we've scored this year." 
The Golden Panthers continued to create quality chances to add to their lead throughout the rest of the half, including back-to-back chances by senior Mergim Ameti with a little less than twenty minutes before the halftime whistle. 
First, around the seventeenth minute, Ameti took a direct free kick. Going for goal, he could only watch as his shot aimed towards the upper corner flashed inches above the crossbar. 
Then, about a minute later, Ameti found himself open in the box with the ball at his feet, only to watch his shot sail high for a second time. 
When the halftime whistle blew, the score still remained 1-0 in the Golden Panthers favor. Zummo said heading into the second half, it was important for the Golden Panthers to keep up the pressure. 
"It was real good to make sure we said, we need to maintain the pressure, keep it up, keep up the intensity, the confidence, and that definitely showed cause we had the ball most of the half," he said. 
The Golden Panthers would indeed keep the ball in the Hornets end for large portions of the second, and they would be rewarded with two more goals. 
First, it was Ameti finding the back of the net around the 21' minute despite his first half struggles when he collected the ball just outside the box from straightaway, turned, and fired his shot home into the bottom left corner. 
Then, with under five minutes left to go, Thomas tallied his second goal of the game, blasting in from a few yards out a ground cross into the box from the right baseline by fellow senior Liam Lilienthal. 
Zummo said Thomas has "been scoring goals all year." 
"He gets himself in good positions and he's such a big, strong kid that he's able to somehow keep the ball even when it doesn't look like he's gonna be able to and finish," he said. 
In addition to seniors showing up on the offensive side of the ball, it was the same on the defensive side, with senior goalkeeper Billy Troast, who finished with ten saves on the night, leading the way.
